content:
would like to know if there is a preferred way to optimize them.

I ... would like to know if there is a preferred way to optimize them.

I don't think one way would be better than then other. It's entirely up to you how to do it. It may also depend on how many filters (or filter actions) you're planning to use.

Also, I seem to recall seeing in the filter help pages that it is preferable to have local storage for filters as opposed to having the mail server sort them out. Why is that?

The filtering happens locally in Thunderbird, not on the server. Thus e.g. filtering on the message body would only work when the entire message has been downloaded, not just the headers. I don't think Thunderbird can do server side filtering.

content:
On old computer, do this: - start thunderbird and click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird. you are now in the profile. messages from IMAP account will be in the imapmail folder 

  and messages for POP or Local Folders will be in the Mail folder. you will see entries such as inbox, inbox.msf, sent, sent.msf, etc.

- copy the desired folder to external media

On new computer, do this: - install the importexport addon of not already done - create new folders in Local Folders for each folder to be imported - highlight the first new local folder, rightclick, and select the importexport option to import mbox - select one of the folders in the Mail folder on external media and import to the new folder. DO NOT do this for the .msf files, as those are just indexes that will be automatically rebuilt. - repeat the above for each folder. -

content:
You can only add a filter "block list" once. It has to be a unique name. But you can then add multiple filter rules underneath that filter.

Having said that, the attempt to fight spam with static filter rules is futile. Use the built-in junk mail controls instead. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

content:
Hello there

The device you are working on cannot receive emails as you write. Sending is going well, okay, can I ask?

When it comes to hereI can I ask you whether the sending and receiving settings have been completed correctly and you do not have any disturbing software on your computer?

try checking in trouble shoot mode for Thunderbird to see if your connections are okay to use with the add-ons disabled? Restart Thunderbird. If you do not receive a response or progress in the problem, check whether your safe mode for Win or the similar OS is hiding a bad software installation in your PC.

Back to not being able to receive and being excluded from what was described above. Can you send us the port numbers and all of the outgoing messages and incoming settings?(they can be found in the incoming email settings en outgoing server settings) per screenshot? These may have been entered incorrectly or may have changed after an update. Your AV software should be checked to see if it is set too high in security mode or if active scans are preventing your process from sending emails, they should be stopped for a while.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-to-make-screenshots

Greetings Firefox volunteer

content: Here is what I do: - install addon - either thunderHTMLedit (my favorite), or HTML source editor - right-click the prior message and click 'edit as new' - that's simpler than creating a new message and using copy/paste and accomplishes the same thing. - using the addon, click to show the actual HTML and there delete the original URL and paste in the new one. - works every time and I like seeing the actual HTML so I know it's right.
creator: davidsk

content:
That content is in what is called the profile. if the old computer is windows, and if you didn't customize locations of folders, do this - start old PC and do NOT start thunderbird - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media - on new computer, exit thunderbird if running - copy the thunderbird folder from external media to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the default profile. - start thunderbird and your old profile, including accounts and folders, should appear.

For future reference, the user is responsible to saving the profile, as thunderbird does not have an online cloud server to do that for users.
creator: davidsk
